content: the piper headband crochet written pattern by chelsea carsen this is an original crochet written pattern and design by chelsea carsen of @chelseacrochets_ on instagram and @chelseacarsen_ on tiktok distribution alteration and/or copy of the written pattern name or likeness of overall design is prohibited as is not giving credit to pattern designer when selling your physical recreation online or in person feel post to post your recreations on social media with me tagged i would love to see what you make pattern breakdown the piper headband is constructed all in one this includes the ties meaning you will not have to fasten off and reattach your yarn during this project until the very end the piper headband begins with the creation of a long spiral tie followed by the body of the headband and then ending with the second tie this pattern can be made with any yarn weight 2-4 and is also made to measure meaning you can adjust the size as needed because of this there is no specific gauge materials needed 40-45 grams of any yarn ranging from sport weight 2 to light worsted 4 4mm- 6mm hook depending on yarn type measuring tape tapestry needle scissors stitches to know us terminology chain- chain slip_stitch- slip_stitch single_crochet- single_crochet symbols to know double_crochet- double_crochet half_double_crochet- half_double_crochet brackets indicate the half_double_crochet increase- half double total number of stitches crochet increase that are in that row half_double_crochet decrease- half double crochet decrease ps- puff @chelseacrochets_ 2 yo- yarn over headband measurments the piper headband can be easily adjusted in size to fit anyone the best way to measure your headband for the perfect fit is to measure the circumference of your head take that number and divide it by 3 you are dividing your measurement by three because the body of the piper headband is worked into three different sections starting with the half_double_crochet increase row then the second section with the puff row and the third section being half_double_crochet decrease row before starting the construction of the final tie my headband measures 22 inches in length not including the ties 22 ÷ 3 = 7 3 this means that each section of the body of my headband needs to measure approximately 7 inches in length for a total of 22 inches for me this worked up to be 16 row in sections 1 and 3 and 15 row for section 2 of my headband this row count includes the decrease/ increase row these numbers could vary for you depending on yarn type hook size and gauge used while crocheting so i recommend stopping and measuring section 1 and multiplying that number by 3 to ensure proper fit @chelseacrochets_ 3 long spiral ties using a loose relaxed gauge chain 90 + 1 in the second to last chain work 3 single_crochet place 3 single_crochet into every stitch for 20 stitches this creates approximately 6 distinct spirals after spirals have been created turn your foundation chain to expose the back
